bibl.title: Letter from Frank F. Law to Philip Showalter Hench, September 17, 1943

div1.p: Law informs Hench that Cornwell's latest painting will be unveiled soon and that he will receive an invitation to attend the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Frank F. Law to Philip Showalter Hench, September 17, 1943
div1.opener:
John Wyeth & Brother
Incorporated
Manufacturing Chemists,
Philadelphia 3,
1600 Arch Street
September 17, 1943
Lt. Colonel Philip S. Hench
Station Hospital
Camp Carson, Colorado
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I appreciate your letter of September 12, requesting
us to send a set of our pictures to General Hillman at the Sur-
geon General's office. Our Promotional Department has been in-
structed to send it and as soon as it goes forward, I shall
write to General Hillman and send you a copy of my letter.

We are going to unveil Dean Cornwell's latest painting
on Friday, November 5, at the Warwick in Philadelphia. It is of
Proctor, who is known as the Father of American Pharmacy. As a
fellow alumnus who has been good enough to attend all our unveil-
ings to date, you will receive a formal invitation but I wish to
take this opportunity to tell you that if you are in the East and
can come, we would be very happy to see you and would appreciate
your attendance.

You may wonder why we departed from medical men in this
painting but the series, as you know, is called Pioneers of Amer-
ican Medicine, so to give the series balance and in justice to
pharmacists, we are giving them the credit that is due them. You
have doubtless seen our advertisements of the Pioneer series in
Time, News Week, New Yorker, Fortune, Parents, Good Housekeeping,
Atlantic, Harpers and Hygeia, and can appreciate more than most
doctors that Wyeth is really trying to give the forgotten man,
the doctor, credit for his accomplishments.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, JOHN WYETH & BROTHER, Inc.
Frank F. Law
President FFL:s
